content: Your name is Heidi. You are an assistant that provides knowledge of the gaming, programming help, among other basic tasks. If you are unsure of a user's question, you ask the user to clarify.

<@990351294290092093> I built a program to read data from one MAC address, but not multiple. I have a graph in plotly and a table in HTML/JS that fetches this data, but the visuals and table records are skewed since the program is now picking multiple addresses. I'll firt show you the graph.js file for the graph, then script.js for the table. My goal is to generate as many graphs as there are MAC addresses. Later I will want to implement a feature to group them together.

Sure, I'd be happy to help you with this issue. Could you please provide the 'graph.js' and 'script.js' files so I can understand better how your program is currently set up? It'd also be useful to know what languages or libraries you're currently working with. Are you using any frameworks or particular programming languages besides JavaScript and HTML?

<@990351294290092093> document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', async function() {
    try {
        const response = await fetch('http://192.168.68.114:3000/api/graph_data');
        if (!response.ok) {
            throw new Error(`HTTP error! status: ${response.status}`);
        }
        const rawData = await response.json();

        let oneDayAgo = Date.now() - 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000000000;  // current time in ms minus 24 hours in ms

        let data = rawData
        .filter(item => item.Timestamp[0] >= oneDayAgo)  // filter out old data
        .map(item =>  ({
            Timestamp: new Date(item.Timestamp[0] / 1000000).toLocaleString(), // Convert nanoseconds to milliseconds and create a Date, then convert it to a locale string
            Temperature: item.Temperature[0],
            Light: item.Light[0],
            Moisture: item.Moisture[0],
            Conductivity: item.Conductivity[0]
        }));


        const timestamps = data.map(item => item.Timestamp);
        const temperature = data.map(item => item.Temperature);
        const light = data.map(item => item.Light);
        const moisture = data.map(item => item.Moisture);
        const conductivity = data.map(item => item.Conductivity);

        // Compute min and max values for each data category
        const temperatureRange = [Math.min(...temperature), Math.max(...temperature)];
        const moistureRange = [Math.min(...moisture), Math.max(...moisture)];
        const lightRange = [Math.min(...light), Math.max(...light)];
        const conductivityRange = [Math.min(...conductivity), Math.max(...conductivity)];

        let chartData = {
            labels: timestamps,
            datasets: [
                {
                    label: 'Temperature',
                    backgroundColor: 'rgba(255, 165, 0, 0.75)',  // orange with 75% opacity
                    borderColor: 'rgba(255, 165, 0, 0.75)',  // orange with 75% opacity
                    hoverBackgroundColor: 'rgba(255, 165, 0, 1)',  // orange with full opacity
                    hoverBorderColor: 'rgba(255, 165, 0, 1)',  // orange with full opacity
                    data: temperature
                },
                {
                    label: 'Light',
                    backgroundColor: 'rgba(0, 200, 0, 0.75)',
                    borderColor: 'rgba(0, 200, 0, 0.75)',
                    hoverBackgroundColor: 'rgba(0, 200, 0, 1)',
                    hoverBorderColor: 'rgba(0, 200, 0, 1)',
                    data: light
                },
                {
                    label: 'Moisture',
                    backgroundColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 200, 0.75)',
                    borderColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 200, 0.75)',
                    hoverBackgroundColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 200, 1)',
                    hoverBorderColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 200, 1)',
                    data: moisture
                },
                {
                    label: 'Conductivity',
                    backgroundColor: 'rgba(200, 0, 0, 0.75)',
                    borderColor: 'rgba(200, 0, 0, 0.75)',
                    hoverBackgroundColor: 'rgba(200, 0, 0, 1)',
                    hoverBorderColor: 'rgba(200, 0, 0, 1)',
                    data: conductivity
                }
            ]
        };

(graph.js part 1)

OK, thank you for sharing part of your `graph.js` file. Could you also share the remaining parts of that file? Also, you mentioned earlier that you would show me the 'script.js' file for the table, so I would appreciate if you could provide that file as well. 

From what I see so far, you're fetching data from an API, filtering out old data from the past 24 hours, and mapping the data into more readable formats to plot. Currently, it seems to handle data from a single MAC address.

To accommodate data from multiple MAC addresses, your program will need to group or map the data by MAC address first before it goes through this process. In essence, we're looking at potentially refactoring this part of your code to create multiple datasets, one for each MAC address. It would be very helpful to see the rest of the `graph.js` and `script.js`, to understand exactly how the data is fetched and visualized, and thus give a more accurate suggestion.
